Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Exploring Social, Ecological, and Hydrological Regime Shifts in the Logone Floodplain of Cameroon

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will focus on the impact of human activities and climate change on African floodplains. African floodplains are an excellent example of coupled human-natural systems because they exhibit strong interactions among multiple social, ecological, and hydrological systems. The intra-annual and inter-annual variations in the area, depth, and duration of seasonal flooding have direct and indirect impacts on ecosystems and human lives and livelihoods. The researchers will develop an integrated computer model that simulates the dynamic couplings among social, ecological and hydrological systems of the Logone floodplain in Cameroon. The model will allow them to simulate the impacts of climate change scenarios and human modifications of the landscape on the social, ecological, and hydrological systems. Fishermen in the Logone floodplain have been modifying the floodplain's hydrology by constructing thousands of individually owned fish canals. The cumulative effect of these canals may equal the impact of large-scale dams. The devastating impact of large-scale dams on African floodplains has been well documented, but what is less clear is how smaller, slower changes like the fish canals may result in regime shifts that have equally disastrous consequences. If the floodplain is characterized by critical transitions, the gradual increase in fish canals may result in a sudden and catastrophic transition equivalent to the impact of large-scale dams. The integrated computer model will enable researchers to examine the nature of the regime shift. The project brings together a team of researchers from a broad range of disciplines and will use a transdisciplinary approach to investigate coupled human and natural systems using a combination of field research, remote sensing analysis, and modeling.

The project will contribute to the sustainable management of African floodplains, which are of enormous ecological and economic importance, by developing an integrated computer model that will permit stakeholders to evaluate the impact of different human activities and climate change scenarios. The project will educate and train graduate and undergraduate students at the Ohio State University and at Maroua University in Cameroon in quantitative and qualitative, transdisciplinary approaches to the study and management of coupled human and natural systems. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seasonal floods are extremely important for the livelihoods of tens of thousands of fishers, herders, and farmers in the Logone Floodplain, Cameroon. The greater the floods, the greater the productivity of the floodplain. Our team of researchers from the Ohio State University and the University of Maroua in Cameroon collaborated in an interdisciplinary study that combined ethnographic research of the fishery system; spatial analysis of fish canals; remote sensing of flooding patterns; hydraulic modeling of flooding patterns; hydroclimatic analysis of past climate and modeling of future climates; and the development of an integrated model that simulates the dynamics couplings between floods, fish and fishers. We used these research strategies to examine the role of fish canals in the coupled human and natural system of the floodplain and have found the following.

First, analysis of satellite images of flooding patterns in the floodplain show that fish canals have an impact on the hydraulics: in the part of the floodplain that has seen an exponential growth of canals, we find earlier and faster flood recession. 

Second, floodplain fisheries are highly productive and adapted to the natural boom-and-bust dynamics of the floodplain. We have found no evidence that the removal of fish from fishing canals has an unsustainable impact on fish populations. However, the impact of canals on flooding patterns may indirectly impact fish populations, especially if their numbers continue to grow. 

Third, the number of canals continues to grow for several reasons: canals are an effective fishing technique that catches the most fish; canals require a significant investment of labor and capital and fishermen are reluctant to give up their investments; and (c) canals allow fishermen to marry multiple wives and grow their family, which provides additional labor. 

Fourth, our hydroclimatic study indicates that future temperatures will increase but rainfall will decrease within the Logone watershed. Changes in rainfall across the watershed likely increase variability in flooding patterns and may impact fish production.

Fifth, we found that the effects of fish canals can be included in hydrodynamic simulations using a simple modification to existing hydraulic model codes. This enabled us to simulate the effect of future climate change on dynamics of inundation within depressions on the floodplain.

Sixth, we found that fish catches are highly variable over space and time. How much fishers catch varies by year, place, and fishing technique. Canal fishing is more sensitive to inter-annual variability in flooding and fish production than other techniques. The combination of high capital investments and high variability may lead to inequality among fishers. 

Seventh, results from simulations with the integrated model show that canal fishing is well adapted to the boom-and-bust dynamics of floodplain fishery because it catches fish that would otherwise die of natural causes. It is the most productive strategy in years with good flooding and is, surprisingly, associated with higher fish biomass. 

The project had two broader impact aims: contributing to the sustainable management of African floodplains; and training graduate and undergraduate students at the Ohio State University and Maroua University in the transdisciplinary study of coupled systems. 

We contributed to sustainable management of the floodplain through capacity building at two NGOs that are working on behalf of floodplain inhabitants: the Cameroonian Association for Environmental Education (ACEEN) and the Center for Research and Development of Pastoralism (CARPA). We trained members of these NGOs in data collection and analysis of coupled systems and shared data that they used in their outreach and development activities. We have also discussed the preliminary findings of our research project with stakeholders from the Logone floodplain in a workshop in Ngaoundere, Cameroon and synthesized the findings in a policy brief aimed at officials at regional, national, and international levels.

We contributed to training students in the transdisciplinary study of coupled systems in different ways. First, we trained postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students at Ohio State in the interdisciplinary study of coupled systems. Second, we supported the research of nine graduate students at the University of Maroua. Third, we trained twenty-five MA and PhD students from the University of Maroua and Ngaoundere in research and modeling of Coupled Human and Natural Systems (CHANS) during a four-day workshop in Cameroon in May 2017. 

We have presented papers at numerous national and international conferences and have several papers published, planned, and in the pipeline, one undergraduate thesis, one dissertation, and three agent-based models. In addition, we contributed to the "Rome Declaration" developed at the Freshwater, Fish and the Future conference of the Food and Agriculture Organization and published a short film about canal fishermen.
